docs.snippet: The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that it had detected “transmissions consistent with” flight recorders, possibly from the missing jet.
docs.lead_paragraph: The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that it had detected “transmissions consistent with” flight recorders, possibly from the missing jet.

headline.main: Search Crews Detect Signals They Say May Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
headline.print_headline: Search Crews Detect Signals They Say May Be From Missing Malaysian Jet

docs.snippet: The focus of the investigation returned to two people on board with expertise — the pilot and his first officer.
docs.lead_paragraph: The focus of the investigation returned to two people on board with expertise — the pilot and his first officer.
docs.abstract: Investigation into disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 shifts to include anyone on board with navigation or aircraft background in response to evidence that plane was deliberately diverted from its route and, after communication was lost, navigated by someone with expertise; development brings new scrutiny to pilot and first officer, Capt Zaharie Ahmad Shah and Fariq Abdul Hamid.

headline.main: Passengers and Crew of Missing Plane Scrutinized for Aviation Skills
headline.print_headline: Passengers and Crew of Missing Plane Scrutinized for Aviation Skills

byline.contributor: Kirk Semple reported from Kuala Lumpur, and Michael Forsythe from Sepang, Malaysia.
byline.original: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

docs.snippet: Experts were poring over military radar data that seemed to indicate that the missing Malaysian flight had turned west and stayed aloft long after its last contact with ground controllers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Experts were poring over military radar data that seemed to indicate that the missing Malaysian flight had turned west and stayed aloft long after its last contact with ground controllers.
docs.abstract: "Official says investigators are examining data seeming to show that missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner was still in automated communication with satellite systems, and may therefore still have been airborne, for hours after ground controllers last heard from it;" information adds to growing belief that jet turned off course after contact was lost and could have flown hundreds of miles west.

headline.main: Jet Hunt Shifts as Findings Hint at Longer Flight
headline.print_headline: Jet Hunt Shifts After Data Hints at Longer Flight

byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald reported from Washington and Thomas Fuller from Sepang, Malaysia. Reporting was contributed by Michael Forsythe from Sepang, Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong, Alan Cowell from London, Gardiner Harris from New Delhi and Christopher Drew, Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt from Washington.
byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and THOMAS FULLER

docs.snippet: Malaysia’s defense minister said satellite images taken Sunday showed 122 objects floating southwest of Australia.
docs.lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s defense minister said satellite images taken Sunday showed 122 objects floating southwest of Australia.
docs.abstract: Malaysia’s defense minister says satellite sightings of 122 objects floating southwest of Australia in Indian Ocean are most credible lead so far in search for Malatysia Airlines Flight 370; eleven aircraft and five ships are scouring the target area.

headline.main: New Satellite Images Said to Be ‘Credible Lead’ in Malaysia Jet Hunt
headline.print_headline: New Images Said to Be ‘Credible Lead’ in Jet Search

byline.contributor: Keith Bradsher reported from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and Nicola Clark from Paris. Michelle Innis contributed reporting from Sydney, Australia, and Kirk Semple from Kuala Lumpur.
byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER and NICOLA CLARK

docs.snippet: As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane continues, experts and investigators have attempted to construct a portrait of Flight 370 with what is known.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane continues, experts and investigators have attempted to construct a portrait of Flight 370 with what is known.
docs.abstract: "Interviews with experts and investigators reveal a portrait, albeit incomplete, of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and the search to find it;" more than two weeks after flight disappeared, unbridled speculation surrounds the unfolding global drama.

headline.main: A Routine Flight, Till Both Routine and Flight Vanish
headline.print_headline: A Routine Flight, Till Both Routine and Flight Vanish

byline.contributor:
Kirk Semple reported from Kuala
Lumpur and aboard Malaysia Airlines
Flight 318. Reporting was
contributed by Michael Forsythe
and Chris Buckley from Sepang,
Malaysia; Keith Bradsher from
Hong Kong; Edward Wong from
Beijing; Rahman Roslan from
Kuala Lumpur; Nicola Clark from
Paris; Thomas Erdbrink from
Tehran; Jad Mouawad and Christopher
Drew from New York; and
Eric Schmitt, Michael S. Schmidt
and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.
Amy Qin and Mia Li contributed
research from Beijing.
byline.original: By PHILIP P. PAN and KIRK SEMPLE

docs.snippet: Australian authorities said that they were investigating reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the plane’s data and voice recorders.
docs.lead_paragraph: Australian authorities said that they were investigating reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the plane’s data and voice recorders.

headline.main: Ship Reports Getting Signal That Could Be Black Box of Missing Jet
headline.print_headline: Ship Reports Getting Signal That Could Be Black Box of Missing Jet

byline.contributor: Chris Buckley contributed reporting from Hong Kong, Nicola Clark from Paris, and Michelle Innis from Sydney, Australia.

docs.snippet: A week after the plane disappeared, the trail is even colder as the search now sprawls from the snowy peaks of the Himalayas to the empty expanses of the southern Indian Ocean.
docs.lead_paragraph: A week after the plane disappeared, the trail is even colder as the search now sprawls from the snowy peaks of the Himalayas to the empty expanses of the southern Indian Ocean.
docs.abstract: Long series of errors and delays, like missed radar blip, by Malaysian government has made the geographically vast and technologically complex task of finding Malaysian Airlines Flight 370 far more difficult.

headline.main: Series of Errors by Malaysia Mounts, Complicating the Task of Finding Flight 370
headline.print_headline: Series of Missteps by Malaysia Mounts, Complicating the Task of Finding Flight 370

byline.contributor: Chris Buckley contributed reporting from Sepang, Nicola Clark from Paris, and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.
byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

docs.snippet: The pilot did not mention any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane.
docs.lead_paragraph: The pilot did not mention any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane.
docs.abstract: "Malaysian official reveals last transmission from Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah of Malaysian Airlines Flight 370 came after plane's signalling system was disabled, fueling speculation that one or both pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane;" suspicion of foulplay has refocused case, as officials brief representatives from 22 countries that will aid in coordinated search along two corridors where plane may have wound up.

headline.main: Timing of Report by Flight’s Pilot Focuses Inquiry
headline.print_headline: Timing of Report by Flight’s Pilot Focuses Inquiry

byline.contributor: Michael Forsythe contributed reporting from Sepang, Malaysia, and Kirk Semple from Kuala Lumpur.
byline.original: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

docs.snippet: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
docs.lead_paragraph: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
docs.abstract: "American officials say first turn to the west that diverted missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its planned route was carried out through a computer system that was most likely programmed by someone in plane’s cockpit;" fact reinforces belief of investigators that plane was deliberately diverted and that foul play was involved, and increases focus on plane's captain and first officer.

headline.main: Lost Jet’s Path Seen as Altered via Computer
headline.print_headline: Lost Jet’s Path Seen as Altered via Computer

byline.contributor: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher contributed reporting from Sepang, Malaysia, and Edward Wong from Beijing.
byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

docs.snippet: Malaysian authorities were struggling to interpret data showing what could be the lost Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 veering off course and hundreds of miles from its last known position.
docs.lead_paragraph: Malaysian authorities were struggling to interpret data showing what could be the lost Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 veering off course and hundreds of miles from its last known position.
docs.abstract: "Malaysian military admits that it recorded, but initially ignored, radar signals from the last known location of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, suggesting that plane may have turned away from its original course;" data shows unidentified aircraft headed west out into Indian ocean, prompting officials to expand search area to take in 27,000 square nautical miles; military is now sharing data with American agencies.

headline.main: Signals on Radar Puzzle Officials in Hunt for Malaysian Jet
headline.print_headline: Signals on Radar Puzzle Officials in Hunt for Jet

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong, Patrick Zuo from Beijing, and Eric Schmitt and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.
byline.original: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and THOMAS FULLER
